column1: There are several rock reliefs from the Lullubian period in Sarpol-e Zahab. The town is also identified as the site of the ancient and medieval town of Hulwan.
The population of Sarpol-e Zahab comprises Kurds who speak the Kalhori
column2: Gorani and Sorani (Jaf) dialects of Kurdish. The inhabitants are respectively adherents of Islam (both Shia and Sunni) and Yarsanism.

column1: Sarpol-e Zahab was one of the two major towns most seriously affected by the 2017 Iran–Iraq earthquake.
The area of Sar-e Pol-e Zahab has several more or less well preserved reliefs of the Lullubi kingdom
column2: as well as a Parthian relief.

column1: The most famous of these reliefs is the Anubanini rock relief. Another relief named Sar-e Pol-e Zohab I is about 200 meters away
column2: in a style similar to the Anubanini relief
column3: but this time with a beardless ruler. The attribution to a specific ruler remains uncertain. There are also other Lullubian relief in the same area of Sar-e Pol-e Zahab.
